awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Wearable Grippers for Hemiplegic Patients
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project will be significant. Stroke is one of the leading causes of long-term severe disability. In US alone almost 800,000 people suffer from stroke each year, with 55% to 75% surviving stroke patients have chronic limb impairment that hinders quality of life with significant disability. This wearable gripper will enable these patents to perform basic daily tasks such as holding a walker stably for functional mobility, opening the cap of a jar, putting on clothes, or pouring water into a glass. By regaining control of basic daily activities, not only the quality of life can improve, but the sense of independence can also help rebuild patients? confidence. In certain cases, this could even accelerate functional recovery. The wearable gripper will be designed with look and feel of popular consumer electronics that can easily gain acceptance of patients that can benefit from it. Its price point will also be in the range comparable to consumer electronics. With innovative electromechanical design and intelligent algorithm, this wearable gripper can learn the wearer?s specific need, a truly adaptive helping hand. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is aimed to develop a compact robotic gripper that can be worn on a person?s arm to assist the wearer in performing daily routine chores. The first target user group of this wearable robotic gripper will be hemiplegic patients who lost control of half side of the body. This lightweight robotic gripper can be worn on the affected arm of a hemiplegic patient and work with the functional arm in a coordinated manner to perform a variety of daily chores. An instrumented wristband with haptic feedback can be worn on the functional arm that senses movement of the arm as well as muscle tension; sensor signals are transmitted to the robotic gripper that can interpret wristband signals and maneuver accordingly. The haptic feedback in the wristband allows the wearer to sense gripper movement and make adjustment if needed.  This product must be lightweight and easy to wear with minimal discomfort. Compact sensors, actuators and soft plastics commonly used in wearable consumer devices will be explored. A prototype will be built and preliminary test data will be analyzed to identify key design requirements and engineering specifications for this groundbreaking product.

por.por_cntn:
Stroke is a leading cause of long term disability. Surviving stroke patients are often left hemiplegic or hemiparesis. Having one side of the brain damaged, the limbs on the other side are often disabled. An increasing population of stroke survivors and others are facing enormous difficulties in daily chores, needing assistance from others. Care for stroke survivors costs an estimated $18.8 billion in US in 2008, and lost productivity and premature mortality cost an additional $15.5 billion.

In this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project, we explored the feasibility of commercializing a wearable gripper that could assist patients with hand impairment to perform daily chores more independently. A robotic gripper worn at the forearm of a patient could enable the wearer to grasp an object in lieu of the disabled hand. Working together with the functional hand, the wearable robotic gripper would allow the hemiplegic patient to perform certain daily tasks that would require both hands, such as using a walker stably or removing the cap from a jar.

Three versions of prototypes were designed and built in this project. In total 50 commonly used household items such as kitchen tools, water bottles, and jars were selected and used as target objects for testing the performance of these prototypes. Three key performance metrics were identified for evaluating the wearable gripper design: 1) grasping efficacy, 2) wearability, and 3) user control. Substantial progress was made in all three design aspects in every prototype iteration. In prototype 3, a handle along with a stretchable conductive string allowed a user to control the gripper with simple wrist movement.

During this project period, we met with more than 80 rehabilitation doctors and physical/occupational therapists to discuss this product concept and demonstrate the prototypes. Comments from these professionals were highly positive and encouraging, confirming the potential value proposition of this device. From these customer discovery visits, we also received valuable feedback regarding the features and requirements of the wearable gripper.

As part of the project outcomes, we submitted one US utility patent application and two provisional applications for the design of the wearable gripper.

We will continue to refine the design and build new prototypes with enhanced features and performance. With the institutional review Board (IRB) approval, a series of field tests will be conducted in rehabilitation hospitals and nursing facilities, to further along the design toward commercialization.

Modified by: Haruhiko H Asada
